Hit loriners, Greeks
A resolution which will deny campus parking privileges
to over one-half the student body within four years has recently been passed by the Johns Hopkins Traffic Commission and approved by University President Milton S.
Eisenhower.
The new ruling states, "All students in their first
year of residence at the University, living within a 3A
mile radius of the campus, will be denied parking privileges on campus." It is designed to as to effect all such
students by the academic year 1961-62.
The ruling will go into effect
this fall nd not effect any present students of the University.
Applicable to first-year and
graduate students as well as the
incoming freshmen, the resolution will cover residents of the
Apartdormitories, Bradford
ments and fraternity houses.
According to Jim Michael,
Student Council representative
to the Traffic Commission, the
new ruling is intended "to relieve the problem of available
Parking facilities for the faculty."
Faculty Have Preference
"In my opinion," said Michael,
"if anyone is given preference,
It should be the faculty, due to
their importance. on campus and
to the fact that they must be
present on time for all classes."
University President Dr. Milton
S. Eisenhower, said that he was
"in full sympathy" with the resolution.
Regulations concerning night
and weekend parking will be
Planned during the summer to
go into effect in the fall. Among
tentative plans is one that would
allow students not holding permits to park on campus between
9 p.m and 2 a.m, weekdays and
from 9 p.m. Friday until 2 a.m.
Monday. "This is not definite as
Yet," added Michael.
Reserved Areas
• The dormitory parking lot as
well as all other parking areas
on campus will be reserved for
students and faculty holding
Permits when the new ruling
goes into effect.
"I'm sure the students realize
the importance of having facilities for faculty members first of
all," stated Michael, noting that
there "probably will be some
repercussions."

Dean Notes Incorrect Popular Notion
Concerning Hopkins' Social Sciences
In a discussion of the new
Social Relations department, Dr.
G. Wilson
Shaffer, Dean of
the Homewood Schools, noted
last week that there is, at a
lower educational- level, a popular notion "that Johns Hopkins
is not too strong in the social
sciencel."
But he was quick to cite the
departments of history, political
science and political economy as
the fundamental areas in the
social sciences and to note that
they are "very strong groups" at
Hopkins.
Dean Shaffer also explained
that it is difficult to dramatize
the social sciences, whereas the
pure sciences and medicine lend
themselves readily to publicity,
as is evident in Hopkins' own
television programs, he added.
Denies Trend
Dean Shaffer refused to relate
the recent stress on the humanities and social sciences at Hopkins, as seen in an output of
liberal arts—directed publicity
from the Public Relations Office
and in University President Milton Eisenhower's own words, with
any local trend in pulling away
from the national emphasis on

scientific training and on meeting the demand for increased
numbers of engineers, physicists
and nuclear specialists.
The addition of the Social
Relations department to the curriculum is something that the
University had wanted "for a
long time" to "fill gaps between
departments."
Four Department Sections
A "large number of the faculty" had discussed the creation
of such a program of studies for
"years", and the university now
has "the financial wherewithal"
to implement the idea.
The Social Relations depart-

ment will consist of four sections: cultural anthropology, social theory, social psychology
and demography.
Chairman To Be Chosen
A committee headed by Dr.
George Evans of the Political
Economy department is now in
the process of selecting the new
department's chairman, who will
"probably" be given much room
in determining its other three
members. Dean Shaffer hopes
to have the new chairman at
Hopkins by September.
The Ford Foundation supplied
the funds for the plan earlier
this winter.

Two Humanities Scholars Draw Grants
From Council For Research Completion
Two Johns Hopkins University
humanities scholars have been
awarded grants for "distinguished scholarly accomplishment" by the American Council
of Learned Societies.
Professors Arthur 0. Lovejoy
and Ludwig. Edelstein of the
School of Arts and Science.s were
recently announced as recipients of the awards at the 39th
annual meeting of the Council in
Indiana. The grants are to
assist in the completion of research.
Dr. Lovejoy, emeritus professor of philosophy, is recognized
as "one of the world's most
learned men" by his colleagues.
He received one of ten special
awards of $10,000 presented to
outstanding American scholars
by the Council.
Professor Lovejoy, born in
Berlin in 1873, received his A.B.
degree from the University of
California, his M.A. from Harvard, and numerous honorary
degrees from such universities
as
Johns Hopkins, Harvard,

Princeton, Columbia and Missouri.
Dr. Lovejoy joined the Hopkins faculty as professor of
philosophy in 1910 and became
emeritus in 1938. He is one of
the founders of the American
Association of University Professors. In 59 years he has
authored five books and about
100 papers and articles. At present he is working on two books.
Dr. Edelstein, Hopkins professor of humanistic studies,
received his degrees from the
University of Berlin and the University of Heidelberg. A member of the Hopkins faculty from
1934 to 1947, he later studied as
a Fellow of the American School
of Classical Studies at Athens.
Until 1952, when he became

the first Hopkins interdepartmental professor of humanistic
studies, Dr. Edelstein held positions as professor of classical
